acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 3 from 96 hours LC50=43mg/L of the fish (Goldfish) (ECETOC TR91 (2003) and others.).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) of 1,500mg/kg (DFGOT vol. 4 (1992)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 2,751mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 2,600mg/kg, 3,850mg/kg, and 4,260mg/kg (DFGOT vol. 4 (1992)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Group 2B by IARC (1999) and Category A3 by ACGIH (2002).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Harmful to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity was Category 3 and the bio-accumulation potential was low (log Kow=1.61(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 51%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 3.

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the negative data on germ cell multi-generation tests (dominant lethal tests), absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, and the negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests, micronucleus tests), described in IARC 47 (1989).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the description in IARC 47 (1989), ACGIH (7th, 2002) and CERI Hazard Data 2000-14 (2001): a decrease in pregnancy rates and seminiferous tubule degeneration are observed, though no description is available for the general toxicity to patent animals.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though containing a distorted ring structure.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description of epidemiological cases (CERI Hazard Data 2000-14 (2001), MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003), ACGIH (7th, 2002)): The substance is irritating to the eyes, skin and respiratory tract, though its degree is unknown. The substance should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on human health effects (CERI Hazard Data 2000-14 (2001), MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003), ACGIH (7th, 2002)): "The substance is irritating to the eyes, skin and respiratory tract," "an accidental exposure to a droplet of the substance, which was painless at first and hence left unwashed, caused reddening of the skin associated with pain after few hours of exposure, followed immediately by washing - the affected area resulted in a second-degree burn, with pigmentation remaining for about three years." The substance is thus considered to cause reversible irritation to the skin.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on data on human health effects (CERI-NITE Hazard Data 2000-14 (2001), MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003), ACGIH (7th, 2002), and DFGOT vol. 4 (1992)), the substance is considered to cause "skin sensitization."

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (respiratory system, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "respiratory inflammation, hepatocyte necrosis" (ACGIH (7th, 2001)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 3 Respiratory tract irritation, Narcotic effects
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects)
May cause drowsiness or dizziness (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "eye/nasal/respiratory/skin irritation (CERI Hazard Data 2000-14 (2001)); eye/skin/respiratory irritation, lowering of consciousness (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004)).
